page.title: 19A Life in Peterborough
page.content: Infancy in Peterborough in 1940 meant responses to blackouts, sirens and rationing but little else. The war by-passed it. Childhood saw gradual change and a sense of normality and hope. Estates were built, the town thrived. Weekly visits to the bustling market with a cathedral backcloth were exciting and satisfying. Departmental stores with whizzing tubes; haber- dashers, ironmongers (words almost forgotten) or the village store with its smells of coffee, cheese and soap meant goods were plentiful again. Young adulthood saw a bright future, with new opportunities. Then the concept of the new town was born ... but the old town seemed to die. The Development Corporation took over and the city lost its heart as landmarks were demolished, But, rising like a phoenix has emerged a proud new city.
